botanical_details.potentially_harmful: Ingestion may cause severe discomfort, skin irritant. Wear gloves and other protective equipment when handling
botanical_details.genus: Helleborus can be rhizomatous, herbaceous or semi-evergreen perennials forming a clump of pedate basal leaves, or evergreen with erect, leafy stems. Large, bowl-shaped flowers are borne in loose clusters in late winter or spring

how_to_grow.cultivation: Often forced for earlier flowering and sold for indoor or outdoor Christmas display. Place in a cool place indoors and after flowering gradually acclimatise to outdoor conditions before planting out in the garden. Thrives in neutral to alkaline soils that are moist, fertile and humus-rich. Partial shade is ideal but can tolerate full sun if the soil is not prone to drying out. Provide shelter from strong, cold winds. Mulch annually in autumn. For further details see hellebore cultivation
how_to_grow.propagation: Divide mature clumps in spring after flowering or in early autumn
how_to_grow.pruning: Remove faded or damaged foliage as the flowers appear
how_to_grow.pests: Hellebore aphid, hellebore leaf miner and snails may be a problem
how_to_grow.diseases: May be subject to hellebore leaf spot and hellebore black death
